bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, April 14, 1948

div1.p: Hench suggests several ways to write the courtesy line for items loaned by Emilie Lawrence Reed for the Hall of Fame program. He inquires about Lawrence Reed's time at Pinar del Rio.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed and Blossom Reed, April 14, 1948
div1.opener:
April 14, 1948
General Walter L. Reed
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
Please see the enclosed letter I have just sent to Miss Bertha L.
Lyons of the Hall of Fame. In my opinion the courtesy line in several in-
stances should be simply “By courtesy of Mrs. Walter Reed”. There is only
one possible reason as I see it, why this should not be done. Some people,
seeing the program, might bother your mother by writing directly to her asking
for the loan of items, and it might bother Mrs. Blossom to have to answer
them. I don't believe too many might write and it would seem proper to me
to mention your mother's name alone; otherwise, the credit line might in-
clude both of your names or “By courtesy of the Reed family”.
Please advise Miss Lyons how you wish these credit lines to read.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P. S.: General Reed: I believe you were stationed for a short time at Pinar
del Rio. Do you remember much about it? The cuartel etc? Do you remember
that your father's visit to Pinar and the incidence of the soldier who caught
yellow fever in a prison cell changed the course of his investigations. I
visited Pinar last month and tried to locate the old cuartel. I took various
photos. If you were yourself stationed at Pinar, I would like to bring these
along the next time we meet, to see whether you could identify them.
